hero.title: Texas Solar Homeowners Savings Report
hero.subtitle: Navigating the energy market to find the best plan to maximize your savings

section1.subtitle: Lessons from real Texas solar owners
section1.quote1: Switching to the right retail plan saved homeowners upwards of $500/year or more

textBlock1.value: Distributed solar is an important part of Texas’ energy future. Investing in local energy solutions like rooftop solar improves the reliability of the Texas energy grid but without state incentives or a statewide net metering policy, many consumers who want solar don’t know where to start or what adding solar means for their utility bills. The economics of rooftop solar varies dramatically, based upon customer-selected rate plans from competitive energy retailers, a fixture of Texas’s unique, deregulated electricity market.

In the last year using Smart Meter Texas data, we’ve analyzed the energy usage and energy production patterns of more than 300 Texas solar owners and compared them to available retail electricity plans in their area. This free service is available to anyone in Oncor and Centerpoint service territories. What we found shows that a solar owner’s choice of retail plan can have a big impact on the savings (average savings of $390/year) their solar arrays provide and often solar owners are on the wrong plan.

textBlock2.value: Being on the right plan can help more people make the switch to solar with confidence while also making valuable contributions to the resiliency of the Texas. There are hundreds of Retail Electricity plans available from providers. To help you compare, we’ve categorized plans into three basic groups:

planDefinitions.definition:
1:1 Buyback plans offer the same kilowatt-hour (kWh) credit for solar energy you export to the grid as the rate you pay for using a kWh from the grid.

Depending on the rate per kWh you are paying, these plans are often better suited to solar arrays that export more electricity to the grid.

Partial Buyback plans also offer compensation for exported solar energy, but at a smaller rate than they charge for importing energy from the grid. The actual import and export rates can vary considerably across this broad class of plans.

If you are a solar owner who uses most of the energy you generate directly in your home rather than exporting it to the grid, this type of plan may offer the shortest payback for your solar investment.

With Free Nights plans, as the name implies, you are not paying for electricity at night.

For some users that have appliances or electric vehicles that use a lot of electricity at one time, timing when they draw power can lower your monthly electricity bill and maximize the value of your solar investment.

textBlock3.value: In our study, approximately 3 out of every 4 solar homeowners were recommended switching to a 1:1 Buyback plan. For most of the remaining homeowners, a Partial Buyback plan was the most appropriate.

textBlock4.value: Finding the most appropriate plan type depends largely on knowing how much energy you are taking from (i.e. importing) vs giving back to (i.e. exporting) the grid.This measure is referred to as your export/import ratio.

For example, if in a given month you import 1000 kWh and export 400 kWh of solar energy (back through your meter), your export/ratio would be 40%.  A lower ratio means you’re using most of the solar energy at home immediately as soon as you make it. A higher ratio means you are generating more solar energy than you need and sending the excess back to the grid.
Our analysis shows that the type of plan best suited for each customer depends on their export/import ratio.

textBlock5.value: For homeowners with a low export/import ratio (or who don't export any excess solar energy at all), the best plan depends on additional factors like when electricity is used throughout the day.

However, once a homeowner begins to export as much energy (or more) as they are importing, the best plan type is almost always going to be a 1:1 Buyback plan. The energy credits that these plans offer for exporting excess solar energy can greatly reduce the annual cost of electricity.

section2.subtitle: Solar value varies widely
section2.overview:
In most places, solar homeowners receive a credit on their monthly utility bill for this excess electricity their system produces. When the excess generation is credited at the same rate as the customer’s consumption this is known as net metering. It ensures solar homeowners receive fair credit for the electricity their systems generate and helps them see a return on their investment into solar. Net metering policies are enacted at the state level. Thirty-eight states require utilities to offer net-metering. Texas is not one of them.

If you buy electricity from a Retail Electricity Provider in Texas, the plan you choose will impact your solar savings as will these factors which vary from household to household: when your home is using the most electricity, how much of your daily electricity needs are served by your solar system versus imported from the grid, and how much electricity your system is exporting to the grid.

Scroll down to see how these factors could play out during a typical day.

steps.text: Your electrical bill depends on how much of your daily electricity is imported from the grid versus generated with a home solar system.
The light gray bars represent your electricity usage each hour throughout a typical day.

A solar system will generate electricity during daylight hours.

The dark gray bars show how much electricity is generated per hour throughout the day.

Solar generation will reduce the amount of electricity imported from the grid.

The circles show your net energy (usage - generation) at each hour, and represent how much electricity is needed from the grid.
Without any solar generation, all of your electricity is imported from the grid.

With a large solar array, you might generate more electricity than you use during portions of the day.

The excess energy is exported back to the grid, and - with solar buyback plans - you can earn money for this.

section3.subtitle: Find the best plan type to fit your needs
section3.overview: When you adjust the different factors impacting solar savings--your overall electricity demand, when your home uses the most electricity, and how much electricity your solar system generates--the analysis tool will show you what plan type is most likely to be the best.

sliderToolTips.homeSize: How much energy you are using from the utility each month depends on a number of factors like how big your home is, how energy efficient it is, how many people live there, and your consumption habits. For simplicity’s sake, we’ve reduced that complex question to just home size.
sliderToolTips.peakTime: When you use electricity in larger amounts can also be relevant to your savings. Most homeowners use more electricity in the evening when they come home from work but things like when you charge your electric vehicle, heat your pool, or do laundry can shift that time.
sliderToolTips.panelSize: If you have solar and know how big your solar array is, select that here. Otherwise, you can leave this value where it is.
